item.title: Randomization Inference Part 2: Attributable Effects
item.description: Introduction In the last post, I presented a framework for performing causal inference in a matched-pair randomized experiment. The Wilcoxon signed rank statistic was introduced, and we saw how it could be used to obtain point and interval estimates of a constant additive effect. This approach will not work when the true effect of treatment differs across individuals, and so in this post, I want to discuss a method for quantifying non-uniform causal effects.

item.title: Randomization Inference Part 1: The Wilcoxon Signed Rank Statistic
item.description: Introduction Last semester, I made my way through the first half of Paul Rosenbaum’s textbook Design of Observational Studies (2010). Rosenbaum is a leading expert in causal inference, an area of statistical research concerned with the identification of causal effects through the analysis of observational data. One piece of advice I’ve heard directed towards researchers in the social sciences who are interested in measuring a causal effect is to get a clear image in their head of the randomized experiment that, were it feasible, ethical, etc.

item.title: About
item.description: Welcome to my website! I am a first year PhD student in the Department of Statistics at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. I hope to use this site to put into writing various thoughts I have as I take courses and eventually perform research. Before graduate school, I lived in Chicago all my life, growing up in the suburbs and then attending the University of Chicago. Outside of school, I enjoy playing basketball, reading philosophy, and listening to music.
